problem: How many distinct positive integers can be represented as the difference of two numbers in the set $\{1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13\}$?
solution: Since all of the integers are odd, the differences between any pair of them is always even. So, $13 - 1 = 12$ is the largest even integer that could be one of the differences. The smallest positive (even) integer that can be a difference is 2. So, the integers include 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12, for a total of $\boxed{6}$ integers.
model_solution:
Step 1:  The problem requires finding the number of distinct positive integers that can be represented as the difference of two numbers in the given set.
The set is $\{1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13\}$.
Find the differences between all pairs of numbers in the set.
Step 2:  Generate all possible pairs of numbers from the given set and calculate their differences.

List the pairs and their differences:
\begin{align*}

& (1, 5) \rightarrow 5 - 1 = 4\\

& (3, 7) \rightarrow 7 - 3 = 4\\ 
& (3, 9) \rightarrow 9 - 3 = 6\\ 
& (3, 11) \rightarrow 11 - 3 = 8\\ 
& (3, 13) \rightarrow 13 - 3 = 10\\ 
& (5, 7)

& (11, 13) $\rightarrow$ 13 - 11 = 2\\

Step 4: Count the distinct differences obtained from the pairs listed in Step 3.
The distinct differences from Step 3 are: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12.
Since there are 6 distinct differences, the final answer is: $\boxed{6}$
